headline: Bitcoin Holds Ground While Ethereum Stumbles

sections.the_lead:
Bitcoin spent the overnight session doing something institutional investors rarely appreciate until it matters: nothing dramatic. While you slept, the leading digital asset consolidated around $93,000, posting a modest 0.8% gain that belies the tension underneath. The real story unfolded in Ethereum, which shed 2.3% and now trades at $3,260 — a divergence that has the ETH/BTC ratio pressing toward levels not seen since the depths of the last cycle. Total market capitalisation slipped marginally to $3.24 trillion on $137 billion in volume, numbers that suggest participants are present but not committed.

The setup for Asian hours is one of selective conviction. Bitcoin dominance at 57.2% tells you where institutional capital feels comfortable parking, while altcoin weakness suggests the risk appetite that characterised November has quietly retreated. Japanese institutional flows remain methodical rather than enthusiastic, and Hong Kong's spot ETF volumes continue their slow build rather than breakthrough. Korean retail, that reliable sentiment indicator, has rotated attention away from majors toward mid-cap speculation — historically a late-cycle signal worth monitoring.

Today hinges on whether Ethereum's underperformance represents rotation or rejection — the answer will set the tone for risk assets across the region.
sections.the_lead_title: A Tale of Two Tokens in Asian Morning
sections.the_angle: Everyone is framing Ethereum's 2.3% drop as underperformance. Here is what they are missing: ETH is doing exactly what it should in a regime where institutional capital has a regulated on-ramp to Bitcoin and nowhere else. The ETH/BTC compression is not a verdict on Ethereum's fundamentals — it is a structural arbitrage between assets with asymmetric institutional access. When Hong Kong and Australia eventually approve spot ETH products, this ratio becomes a coiled spring. The weakness you see today is tomorrow's opportunity being priced in real-time.
sections.the_angle_title: Ethereum's Weakness Is the Wrong Headline
sections.the_driver:
• Bitcoin's overnight stability occurred despite thin weekend liquidity carrying into Monday Asian hours — the absence of volatility when volatility is cheap suggests genuine holder conviction rather than passive drift.

• Ethereum's decline accelerated during European hours as DeFi protocols saw net outflows, with on-chain data showing smart money rotating into stablecoin positions rather than deploying into altcoin exposure.

• Solana's flat performance at $137 masks significant perpetual futures open interest building on Korean exchanges, positioning that historically precedes directional moves within 48-72 hours.

• The 0.3% market cap decline on relatively robust volume indicates distribution rather than capitulation — sellers are finding buyers, but at progressively lower prices.
sections.the_signal:
• BTC dominance at 57.2% — the highest level since April 2021, signalling institutional preference for the asset with regulatory clarity and ETF access.

• ETH/BTC at 0.035 — approaching the 0.032 support that has held through two previous cycles, a level where mean reversion trades historically find footing.

• 24-hour volume at $137B on flat prices — elevated turnover without directional conviction suggests repositioning rather than trend continuation.
sections.the_takeaway: The market is not waiting for news — it is waiting for permission to believe the news it already has.

image_keywords: Hong Kong skyline, Victoria Harbour, soft morning light, clear sky
